sections.title: Locations in Sri Lanka Where Leopards Live

locations.name: Kumana National Park
locations.description: Kumana National Park, situated in Sri Lanka's Eastern Province, is renowned for its diverse birdlife and wetland habitats. The park spans around 35,664 hectares and comprises a range of ecosystems, including mangroves, lagoons, scrublands, and forests. It's a crucial habitat for various bird species, especially during the migratory season.

locations.name: Horton Plains National Park
locations.description: Horton Plains, located in Sri Lanka's central highlands, features a unique landscape characterized by montane grasslands, cloud forests, and scenic vistas. It covers an area of about 3,160 hectares and is known for its rich biodiversity, including rare and endemic flora and fauna.

locations.name: Knuckles Conservation Forest
locations.description: The Knuckles Mountain Range, designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, encompasses the Knuckles Conservation Forest. This area, named after its knuckle-shaped mountain peaks, boasts rugged terrain, dense forests, and an array of ecosystems.

threats.name: Habitat Loss
threats.description: Human activities like deforestation, agriculture, and urbanization lead to habitat fragmentation and degradation, reducing the available space for leopards to roam and hunt.

threats.name: Poaching
threats.description: Illegal hunting and trade pose a threat to Sri Lankan leopards, driven by demands for leopard body parts, skins, or traditional medicinal purposes.
